questionTask.text: What are the different options for the tenant when the lease agreement ends?
What are the responsibilities of the tenant regarding damages and repairs when moving in?
What is the recommendation given to the tenant regarding insurance?

statementsTask.text:
According to source 1, at the end of the lease agreement, the tenant must return all access provided to the landlord or pay a fee. Source 0 states that the landlord and tenant are bound by the terms and conditions until the end of the lease term. However, there is no information in the sources about different options for the tenant when the lease agreement ends.

Sources:
[0] The Landlord and Tenant agree to the terms and conditions and shall be bound until the end of the Lease Term.

When the lease agreement ends, the tenant has three options: (1) continue to lease the premises under the same terms of the agreement under a month-to-month arrangement [1], (2) vacate the premises [2], or (3) terminate the agreement at any time by providing a written notice to the landlord and paying a termination fee [3]. Additionally, if the landlord fails to deliver possession of the premises, the tenant may cancel the agreement and receive a refund of the security deposit and any pre-paid rent or fees [4]. At the end of the lease term, the tenant must surrender the premises in the same or better condition as it was at the beginning of the agreement, except for reasonable wear and tear and damages by the elements [5]. However, if the tenant fails to comply with any financial or material provisions of the agreement, or any duties imposed by statute or state laws, the landlord may terminate the agreement after providing written notice to the tenant [6]. If the tenant vacates or abandons the premises for a certain period of time, the landlord may also terminate the agreement and remove all belongings from the premises [7] [8].

Sources:
[1] Ł - May continue to lease the Premises under the same terms of this Agreement under a month-to-month arrangement.
[2] Ł - Must vacate the Premises.
[3] Ł - Shall have the right to terminate this Agreement at any time by providing at OHDVWBBBGD\V¶ZULWWHQQRWLFHWRWKH/DQGORUGDORQJZLWKDQHDUO\WHUPLQDWion fee of $___________ (US Dollars).
[4] Furthermore, under such failure to deliver possession by the Landlord, and if the Tenant cancels this Agreement, the Security Deposit (if any) shall be returned to the Tenant along with any other pre-paid rent, fees, including if the Tenant paid a fee during the application process before the execution of this Agreement.
[5] Upon the expiration of the term hereof, the Tenant shall surrender the Premise in better or equal condition as it were at the commencement of this Agreement, reasonable use, wear and tear thereof, and damages by the elements excepted.
[6] If the Tenant fails to comply with any of the financial or material provisions of this Agreement, or of any present rules and regulations or any that may be hereafter prescribed by the Landlord, or materially fails to comply with any duties imposed on the Tenant by statute or State laws, within the time period after delivery of written notice by the Landlord specifying the non-compliance and indicating the intention of the Landlord to terminate the Agreement by reason thereof, the Landlord may terminate this Agreement.
[7] If the Tenant vacates or abandons the Premises for a time-period that is the minimum set by State law or seven (7) days, whichever is less, the Landlord shall have the right to terminate this Agreement immediately and remove all belongings including any personal property off of the Premises.
[8] If the Tenant vacates or abandons the Premises, the Landlord shall immediately have the right to terminate this Agreement.

Upon moving in, the Tenant is responsible for maintaining the premises in a clean and sanitary manner at their own expense and surrendering it in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted. The Tenant is also responsible for all damages caused by any pet, regardless of ownership, and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense. If any damage is due to the Tenant's negligence, they shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord. The Tenant shall be notified of the new Owner and their contact details for repairs and maintenance if the Premises is sold. The Landlord shall not be responsible for any utilities or services not mentioned, and the Tenant agrees to hold the Landlord harmless from any claims or damages unless caused solely by the Landlord's negligence.

Sources:
[0] Any other utilities or services not mentioned will be the responsibility of the Tenant.
[1] If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord.
[2] The Tenant is responsible for all damage that any pet causes, regardless of ownership of said pet and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense.
[3] The Landlord shall not be liable for any damage or injury to the Tenant, or any other person, or to any property, occurring on the Premises, or any part thereof, or in common areas thereof, and the Tenant agrees to hold the Landlord harmless from any claims or damages unless caused solely by the Landlord's negligence.
[4] The Tenant shall, at their own expense and at all times, maintain premises in a clean and sanitary manner, and shall surrender the same at termination hereof, in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted.
[5] If the Tenant possesses any mental or physical impairment, the Landlord shall provide reasonable modifications to the Premises unless the modifications would be too difficult or expensive for the Landlord to provide.

The tenant is responsible for inspecting the premises and writing any present damages or needed repairs on a move-in checklist [1]. The tenant is also responsible for all damage that any pet causes, regardless of ownership of said pet and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense [2]. The tenant shall, at their own expense and at all times, maintain premises in a clean and sanitary manner, and shall surrender the same at termination hereof, in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted [3]. The tenant may not make any alterations to the leased premises without the consent in writing of the landlord [4]. If the premises is deemed uninhabitable due to damage beyond reasonable repair the tenant will be able to terminate this Agreement by written notice to the landlord [5]. If said damage was due to the negligence of the tenant, the tenant shall be liable to the landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the landlord [6]. The tenant reserves the right to have the premises inspected by the landlord in the THQDQW¶VSUHVHQFHIRUWKHSXUSRVHRIPDNLQJDZULWWHQ list of damages that exist at the commencement of the tenancy, if the tenant so requests by certified mail within fifteen (15) days of occupancy [7].

[3] The Tenant shall, at their own expense and at all times, maintain premises in a clean and sanitary manner, and shall surrender the same at termination hereof, in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted.
[4] The Tenant may not make any alterations to the leased premises without the consent in writing of the Landlord.
[5] If the Premises is deemed uninhabitable due to damage beyond reasonable repair the Tenant will be able to terminate this Agreement by written notice to the Landlord.
[6] If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord.

The tenant is recommended to purchase renter's insurance at their own expense. This is mentioned in source 0.

Sources:

The recommendation given to the tenant is that they should purchase renter's insurance at their own expense [1].

Sources:
[1] It is recommended that renter's insurance be purchased at the Tenant's expense.

qaTask.answer:
Upon moving in, the Tenant is responsible for maintaining the premises in a clean and sanitary manner at their own expense and surrendering it in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted. The Tenant is also responsible for all damages caused by any pet, regardless of ownership, and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense. If any damage is due to the Tenant's negligence, they shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord. The Tenant shall be notified of the new Owner and their contact details for repairs and maintenance if the Premises is sold. The Landlord shall not be responsible for any utilities or services not mentioned, and the Tenant agrees to hold the Landlord harmless from any claims or damages unless caused solely by the Landlord's negligence.

qaTask.question: What happens if there are disputes between the landlord and tenant?
qaTask.answer:
If a dispute arises during or after the term of the Agreement between the Landlord and Tenant, they shall agree to hold negotiations amongst themselves, in "good faith", before any litigation. The Landlord and Tenant agree to the terms and conditions and shall be bound until the end of the Lease Term. Therefore, if there are disputes between the landlord and tenant, they must negotiate in good faith before any litigation.

Sources:
[0] If a dispute arises during or after the term of this Agreement between the Landlord and Tenant, they shall agree to hold negotiations amongst themselves, in "good faith", before any litigation.
[1] The Landlord and Tenant agree to the terms and conditions and shall be bound until the end of the Lease Term.

qaTask.question: Who is responsible for what, in terms of maintenance and repair?
qaTask.answer:
The Landlord is responsible for repairs to the interior and exterior of the building, and has a manager on the premises that can be contacted for any maintenance or repair. Any other utilities or services not mentioned will be the responsibility of the Tenant. The Tenant is responsible for all damage that any pet causes, regardless of ownership of said pet and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense. The Tenant is also responsible for inspecting the Premises and writing any present damages or needed repairs on a move-in checklist. If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord. If the Premises includes a washer, dryer, freezer, dehumidifier unit and/or air conditioning unit, the Landlord makes no warranty as to the repair or replacement of units if one or all shall fail to operate. After the initial placement of the fresh batteries, it is the responsibility of the Tenant to replace batteries when needed.

Sources:
[0] MAINTENANCE, REPAIRS, OR ALTERATIONS.
[1] The Landlord shall be responsible for repairs to the interior and exterior of the building.
[2]  - The Landlord does have a manager on the Premises that can be contacted for any maintenance or repair at:
[3] Any other utilities or services not mentioned will be the responsibility of the Tenant.
[4] Ł - Agree to inspect the Premises and write any present damages or needed repairs on a move-in checklist.
[5] The Tenant is responsible for all damage that any pet causes, regardless of ownership of said pet and agrees to restore the Premises to its original condition at their expense.
[6] If the Premises is sold, the Tenant is to be notified of the new Owner, and if there is a new Manager, their contact details for repairs and maintenance shall be forwarded.
[7] If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord.
[8] If the Premises includes a washer, dryer, freezer, dehumidifier unit and/or air conditioning unit, the Landlord makes no warranty as to the repair or replacement of units if one or all shall fail to operate.
[9] After the initial placement of the fresh batteries it is the responsibility of the Tenant to replace batteries when needed.

qaTask.question: Who is responsible for what, in terms of maintenance and repair?
qaTask.answer:
The Tenant is responsible for maintaining the premises in a clean and sanitary manner at all times, and must surrender the same in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted [1]. The Tenant may not make any alterations to the leased premises without the written consent of the Landlord [2]. The Landlord is responsible for repairs to the interior and exterior of the building [3]. If the Premises includes a washer, dryer, freezer, dehumidifier unit and/or air conditioning unit, the Landlord makes no warranty as to the repair or replacement of units if one or all shall fail to operate [4]. The Landlord will place fresh batteries in all battery-operated smoke detectors when the Tenant moves into the premises [5]. A monthly "cursory" inspection may be required for all fire extinguishers to make sure they are fully charged [6]. The Tenant agrees to not possess any type of personal property that could be considered a fire hazard such as a substance having flammable or explosive characteristics on the Premises [7]. Items that are prohibited to be brought into the Premises, other than for everyday cooking or the need of an appliance, includes but is not limited to gas (compressed), gasoline, fuel, propane, kerosene, motor oil, fireworks, or any other related content in the form of a liquid, solid, or gas [8]. The Landlord shall not be liable for any damage or injury to the Tenant, or any other person, or to any property, occurring on the Premises, or any part thereof, or in common areas thereof, and the Tenant agrees to hold the Landlord harmless from any claims or damages unless caused solely by the Landlord's negligence [9]. It is recommended that renter's insurance be purchased at the Tenant's expense [10]. If the Premises is deemed uninhabitable due to damage beyond reasonable repair the Tenant will be able to terminate this Agreement by written notice to the Landlord [11]. If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord [12].

Sources:
[1] The Tenant shall, at their own expense and at all times, maintain premises in a clean and sanitary manner, and shall surrender the same at termination hereof, in as good condition as received, normal wear and tear excepted.
[2] The Tenant may not make any alterations to the leased premises without the consent in writing of the Landlord.
[3] The Landlord shall be responsible for repairs to the interior and exterior of the building.
[4] If the Premises includes a washer, dryer, freezer, dehumidifier unit and/or air conditioning unit, the Landlord makes no warranty as to the repair or replacement of units if one or all shall fail to operate.
[5] The Landlord will place fresh batteries in all battery-operated smoke detectors when the Tenant moves into the premises.
[6] A monthly "cursory" inspection may be required for all fire extinguishers to make sure they are fully charged.
[7] The Tenant agrees to not possess any type of personal property that could be considered a fire hazard such as a substance having flammable or explosive characteristics on the Premises.
[8] Items that are prohibited to be brought into the Premises, other than for everyday cooking or the need of an appliance, includes but is not limited to gas (compressed), gasoline, fuel, propane, kerosene, motor oil, fireworks, or any other related content in the form of a liquid, solid, or gas.
[9] The Landlord shall not be liable for any damage or injury to the Tenant, or any other person, or to any property, occurring on the Premises, or any part thereof, or in common areas thereof, and the Tenant agrees to hold the Landlord harmless from any claims or damages unless caused solely by the Landlord's negligence.
[10] It is recommended that renter's insurance be purchased at the Tenant's expense.
[11] If the Premises is deemed uninhabitable due to damage beyond reasonable repair the Tenant will be able to terminate this Agreement by written notice to the Landlord.
[12] If said damage was due to the negligence of the Tenant, the Tenant shall be liable to the Landlord for all repairs and for the loss of income due to restoring the Premises back to a livable condition in addition to any other losses that can be proved by the Landlord.

qaTask.question: What does the lead warning statement say?
qaTask.answer:
The lead warning statement requires landlords to disclose the presence of known lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in pre-1978 housing before renting. Landlords must also provide tenants with a federally approved pamphlet on lead poisoning prevention. The statement also acknowledges that lead exposure is especially harmful to young children and pregnant women. Landlords must disclose whether they have knowledge of lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in the housing, and whether they have reports or records pertaining to it. If known lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards are present in the housing, landlords must explain their presence. The statement emphasizes that lead from paint, paint chips, and dust can pose health hazards if not managed properly.

Sources:
[0] Before renting pre-1978 housing, landlords must disclose the presence of known lead-based paint and /or lead-based paint hazards in the dwelling.
[1] Tenants must also receive a federally approved pamphlet on lead poisoning prevention.
[2] Lead exposure is especially harmful to young children and pregnant women.
[3]  - Landlord has no reports or records pertaining to lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in the housing.
[4]  - Landlord has provided the tenant with all available records and reports pertaining to lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in the housing (list documents below).
[5]  - Known lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards are present in the housing (explain): _______________________________________.

qaTask.question: What does the lead warning statement say?
qaTask.answer:
The lead warning statement requires landlords to disclose the presence of known lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in pre-1978 housing before renting it out [1]. This is because lead from paint, paint chips, and dust can pose health hazards if not managed properly [2]. Landlords must provide tenants with all available records and reports pertaining to lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in the housing [3], and tenants must receive copies of all information listed above [4].

Sources:
[1] Before renting pre-1978 housing, landlords must disclose the presence of known lead-based paint and /or lead-based paint hazards in the dwelling.
[2] Lead from paint, paint chips, and dust can pose health hazards if not managed properly.
[3]  - Landlord has provided the tenant with all available records and reports pertaining to lead-based paint and/or lead-based paint hazards in the housing (list documents below).
[4]  - Tenant has received copies of all information listed above.
